timedActivities.context: Book summit tickets in advance. The elevator lines get long after 10am.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: The icon that launched a thousand postcards
practicalTips: Bring a light jacket for the top

timedActivities.context: Historic café in Saint-Germain. Hemingway and Picasso were regulars.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Where existentialism was invented over espresso

timedActivities.context: Go straight to the Denon wing for Italian masters. Skip the main entrance - use Porte des Lions.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: 3,000 years of human creativity under one roof

timedActivities.context: Bateaux Mouches departs from Pont de l'Alma. Book the dinner option.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Paris glitters differently from the water

untimedActivities.context: Great for vintage shopping and falafel. L'As du Fallafel is the famous one.

timedActivities.context: Former railway station. The Impressionist collection on the 5th floor is unmissable.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Where Monet, Van Gogh, and Renoir live together

timedActivities.context: Take the funicular up to Sacré-Cœur. The view of Paris is worth the climb.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Cobblestones that remember Toulouse-Lautrec

timedActivities.context: Free entry. The dome climb (300 steps) gives the best panoramic view of Paris.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: A wedding cake overlooking the city of light

timedActivities.context: Classic bistro near the Panthéon. Try the duck confit.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: The kind of place where locals actually eat

untimedActivities.context: Across from Notre-Dame. Bring cash - they don't take cards for small purchases.

timedActivities.context: 3 hours 20 minutes. Arrive 30 minutes early for boarding.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Breakfast in Paris, lunch in Amsterdam

timedActivities.context: Drop bags at hotel, grab a stroopwafel from the station.
Tickets sell out weeks in advance. Book online - no walk-ups allowed.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Where a diary became a testament
timedActivities.urgentNote: Tickets MUST be booked online in advance. No exceptions.

timedActivities.context: The prettiest neighborhood. Great for canal-side drinks.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Amsterdam's postcard district

untimedActivities.what: Try Dutch fast food from a wall
untimedActivities.context: Automated vending wall with hot snacks. The kroket is a must-try.

timedActivities.context: Start with the Night Watch, then work backward through the galleries.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Rembrandt's home turf

timedActivities.context: Biggest street market in Europe. Try the herring, stroopwafels, and kibbeling.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: If Amsterdam had a stomach, this would be it

timedActivities.context: Audio guide is excellent. Don't miss the letters section.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: 200 paintings that trace a tortured genius

timedActivities.context: Smaller boats are better than big tourist barges. Some offer wine and cheese.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: The only way to truly understand Amsterdam's layout

untimedActivities.context: In the Jordaan. Get it warm with whipped cream.

timedActivities.what: Morning walk in the city park
timedActivities.context: Rent a bike from the hotel and ride through like a local.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Amsterdam's green lung

timedActivities.context: 4 hours including transfer in Brussels. UK border control happens in Amsterdam.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Under the Channel in style

timedActivities.context: Beautiful Victorian station. The champagne bar is worth a stop.
Market closes at 5pm but restaurants stay open. Padella for fresh pasta.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: London's foodie ground zero

timedActivities.context: Go straight to the Crown Jewels when it opens. Join a Yeoman Warder tour - they're free and hilarious.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: 1,000 years of royal drama

timedActivities.what: Lunch at London's oldest food market
timedActivities.context: Open Thursday-Saturday. Get there before 1pm to avoid the worst crowds.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Every cheese, bread, and cured meat you can imagine

timedActivities.context: Former power station. The Turbine Hall installations are always impressive.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Where a urinal became art history

timedActivities.context: From Tate Modern to Westminster Bridge. Pass Shakespeare's Globe and the London Eye.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: London's best free attraction

timedActivities.context: Book in advance for popular shows. TKTS booth in Leicester Square has same-day discounts.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Broadway's older, more sophisticated sibling

untimedActivities.context: Multiple locations. The bacon naan roll is legendary. Expect queues.

timedActivities.context: Free entry. The Rosetta Stone and Parthenon Marbles are must-sees.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Everything humanity ever stole, beautifully displayed

timedActivities.context: The market has good food stalls. Watch for the opera singers in the main hall.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: London's living room

timedActivities.context: Every monarch since 1066 crowned here. Newton, Darwin, and Dickens are buried inside.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: Where kings become kings

timedActivities.what: Watch the Changing of the Guard
timedActivities.context: Happens at 11am daily in summer, but the palace exterior is best in late afternoon light.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: The world's most famous house

timedActivities.context: Book free tickets in advance. Great sunset spot - arrive 30 minutes early.
timedActivities.emotionalTagline: The best free view in London

untimedActivities.context: The Lamb and Flag, Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese, The George Inn - all have 400+ years of history.
